title: When will a member of China's Politburo Standing Committee visit North Korea?
preds: Looks like Li Zhanshu ( a member of the Standing Committee) will be attending instead of Xi. Still fits the criteria: https://www.voanews.com/a/chinese-president-skip-north-korean-anniversary-event/4561703.html

Li Zhanshu photographed today with arms raised & holding hands with KJU for the 70th anniversary NK Parade.
https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/n-korea-stages-huge-parade-holds-back-on-advanced-missiles/ar-BBN46iM?li=BBnb7Kz&OCID=ansmsnnews11
Affirming. Should know if Li Zhanshu shows in 12 hrs or less

It has been announced that Li Zhanshu will be attending a celebration in Pyongchang on September 8th (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/04/world/asia/china-north-korea-xi-jinping.html). Seeing as this is one day away, it is unlikely that they will change plans within the next 24 hours as the travel arrangements will have had to been set by now. North Korean officials have visited China in recent months, and the continued friendly relations between the two countries has continued. This relationship has been only marginally affected by past international disputes, so given NK does not launch an ICBM within the next few hours this is highly likely to go through.

Li Zhanshu's going, and I imagine if they change it again last minute it will still be someone on the Standing Committee.  In order to lose that, I imagine North Korea would have to do something really ballsy and stupid to merit a public rebuff https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/04/world/asia/china-north-korea-xi-jinping.html
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/chinas-xi-to-send-top-ally-to-north-korea-anniversary/2018/09/04/cec00890-b0ab-11e8-8b53-50116768e499_story.html?utm_term=.bbefc05196df

If Li Zhanshu shows up, this happens.  Holding 1 open because one never knows, but it's pretty much a dead cert.

At present, all possibilities remain open," a source said.

Flipping forecast as there has been no response from China to confirm attendance on 9/9.

Rumors announced by a Singapore based newspaper say Xi Xinping will visit Pyongyang in the days leading up to September 9th. Beijing has declined to confirm the rumors, only affirming the friendship between the two countries.  The 9th marks the 70th anniversary of NK as a country. A visit to Pyongyang by a Chinese diplomat shows willingness from Beijing to engage.
If Xi doesn’t show on 9 Sep, the odds plummet

Opinion article from Sputnik.  US Failing to Keep Up Its End of North Korea Bargain
https://sputniknews.com/analysis/201808281067519831-US-Failing-Bargain-Not-DPRK/ Has this interesting quote from Christine Hong, from @KpolicyO :
  "China's really moved away from a kind of policy of walking more or less in lock-step with US sanctions policy, and they've stated, rightly so, that at this particular moment, when North Korea has made a number of good-faith concessions for the prospect of engagement with the United States, that the United States actually needs to scale back some of its sanctions. Russia has said the same. "

https://www.voanews.com/a/china-north-korea-to-team-up/4535786.html The [Singapore Straits Times] report has not been confirmed by the Chinese Foreign Ministry. The Daily NK online newspaper and the Korea Times newspaper in Seoul also recently speculated that North Korea was preparing for a visit from the Chinese head of state, based in part on reports that Chinese border patrols along the North Korean border have increased, and that Pyongyang has suspended visiting tour groups. If confirmed, it would be the Chinese leader's first visit to the North Korean capital since he took power in 2012, and 13 years after the last visit by a Chinese President, when Xi's predecessor Hu Jintao visited in 2005. https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-is-north-korea-really-willing-to-denuclearize-we-will-soon-find-out/ U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo was scheduled to travel to Pyongyang on Sunday, but that trip was suddenly cancelled on Friday by Mr. Trump, who tweeted that he had asked Mr. Pompeo “not to go to North Korea, at this time, because I feel we are not making sufficient progress with respect to the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula.” It was Mr. Trump’s first admission that talks with North Korea were not going well. The same day, Mr. Trump tweeted his “warmest regards and respect to Chairman Kim and I look forward to seeing him soon.” Mr. Trump, apparently, doesn’t blame Mr. Kim for the lack of progress. Then who, in his mind, is responsible? The answer is China. “Because of our much tougher Trading stance with China, I do not believe they are helping with the process of denuclearization as they once were,” Mr. Trump also tweeted on Friday. He said the Pompeo trip to Pyongyang would be “most likely after our Trading relationship with China is resolved.” So, in Mr. Trump’s mind, the two issues are linked and the trade issue needs to be resolved first. Cancellation of the Pompeo trip now gives more responsibility – and opportunity – to two other leaders who are expected to visit Pyongyang next month. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/25/world/asia/china-north-korea-sanctions.html?login=smartlock&auth=login-smartlock China is less interested in backing the denuclearization efforts because it feels burned by Mr. Trump on trade, according to a Western diplomat with contacts among the Chinese leadership. Its leaders had believed that Mr. Trump would not proceed with the confrontational trade policies he promised during the presidential campaign if China helped him by going along with tougher United Nations sanctions against the North last year, the diplomat said. Chinese officials said Mr. Trump had given such assurances, and they felt betrayed when he went ahead with aggressive tariffs this year, the diplomat said. Mr. Xi’s visit to Pyongyang is likely to be on or near Sept. 9, the 70th anniversary of North Korea’s founding, Chinese analysts said. ...The Chinese government has not formally announced Mr. Xi’s trip — it usually makes such declarations just days ahead of time — but Chinese analysts and Western diplomats say that preparations are underway for him to be in Pyongyang. ...But either way, satellite imagery from the past few weeks suggests that the North is preparing for a bigger parade than in past years, according to 38 North, a website produced by the Washington-based Stimson Center that analyzes North Korea.

If China hasn't denied it then it's probably likely.  An Australian news report says a visit for this event has been a rumor for months (and @AdamRen seems to have seen the writing on the wall a month ago https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/758836).  Past Politburo members have a tendency to go up for ceremonial events so that the political issues are not the only driver for the "exchange" / "cooperation" relationship.  Furthermore, China gets back into the game, can push Americans into bending on their current hard line demands to denuclearize before sanctions end (while also saving face), and can strengthen both private and public acknowledgement of their influence on DPRK.  I don't think China has very much to lose at all, and the fact that Xi is rumored to go and not another of the top 6 suggests that it's a very big deal.   If China responds with a public acknowledgment of plans, I think this is very likely.  A delay could be because it isn't determined yet if Xi will go or another top official, if they'll go for this event or at another time (or more likely, the specific day or length of time), or because they haven't sorted out the details of a visit with DPRK yet.  I would expect an official response from China by mid- or end-of-week, but I'll wait to go higher until then in case they come out and deny the rumor so as not to come off worse by failing to go / failing to respond.

Source: http://www.chinavitae.com/vip/index.php?mode=events&type=cv&id=303 Visits by any Chinese officials (not necessarily those on Politburo) to North Korea from 2003 to 2011averaged 8 per year. When Kim Jung Un became the leader at the end of 2011, visits dropped to an average of 1.5 /yr with 0 visits in 2014, 0 visits in 2016, and 0 in 2017. In 2018, Wang Yi visited in May.  The last time Xi Jinping visited Pyongyang was in 2008. 
In March, Xi publicly stated that he would visit Pyongyang soon.
Xi was invited by Kim Jung Un to attend the 70th founding anniversary festivities on September 9
It may be considered insulting if he doesn't go since KJU has been to China 3 times in recent months. https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/2154235/north-korea-invites-chinese-president-xi-jinping “If Xi actually visits North Korea, bilateral relations will reach a new stage ... of cooperation. China has always opposed chaos on the Korean peninsula and thus wanted the Kim regime to be stable. This will never change.”

https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/2154235/north-korea-invites-chinese-president-xi-jinping
North Korea has invited Chinese President Xi Jinping to visit Pyongyang in September for its national day as relations between the two countries gain pace.  An unnamed North Korean official told South Korean reporters on Friday that Pyongyang had sent an invitation to Xi to celebrate the 70th anniversary of the country’s foundation on September 9.  The anniversary is one of the hermit kingdom’s most important annual holidays, along with the birthdays of late leaders Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il.  If Xi does go, it will be the first trip to North Korea by a Chinese president since Hu Jintao’s visit in October 2005 and since Pyongyang started conducting nuclear and missile tests in 2006. 
   ...Kim has visited China to meet Xi three times since March – the first two times in the lead-up to the summit and the third in June to brief China on the outcome of the talks.
   Liu Ming, from the Centre for Korea Studies at the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences, said North Korea might be trying to use Xi’s presence at the celebrations to suggest the bilateral relationship was back on track.  “North Korea would also look weaker if Xi did not visit given that Kim has visited China three times,” Liu said, adding that Xi gave his word that he would go when Kim visited in March.  “Chinese leaders often made reciprocal visits in Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il’s time, but not in Kim Jong-un’s. The chance of Xi accepting the invitation is quite high.”
   ...Cui Zhiying, director of the Korean Peninsula Research Centre at Tongji University in Shanghai, agreed that North Korea might see Xi’s visit as its first step to becoming a normal state.  ...“If Xi actually visits North Korea, bilateral relations will reach a new stage ... of cooperation. China has always opposed chaos on the Korean peninsula and thus wanted the Kim regime to be stable. This will never change.” https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/2154515/trump-says-he-confident-kim-jong-un-will-follow-contract-they
...While Kim agreed to work toward denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula, which was largely in line with Pyongyang’s stance since 1990s, Trump apparently had a different understanding of what was achieved at the first meeting between North Korea and a sitting US president.  “We agreed to the denuclearisation of North Korea,” he said in the tweet.  
   ...“China, on the other hand, may be exerting negative pressure on a deal because of our posture on Chinese Trade-Hope Not!” said Trump in the tweet.
   ...“President Trump is clearly telegraphing to the North Koreans that there’s distance between China and the United States … and the North Koreans are going to use that to their advantage,” said Joel Wit, a senior fellow at the Stimson Centre, a Washington-based think tank, and founder of 38 North, a website focused on North Korea issues.  “They’re going to constantly play off the US against China, and that doesn’t strengthen our position, it weakens our position with North Korea,” Wit said. https://www.voanews.com/a/china-rebuffs-trump-s-blame-in-north-korea-denuclearization-fallout/4477861.html
...“This is totally baseless. China's position on the Korean peninsula is consistent and clear. We will steadfastly play a positive role and make constructive contributions towards pushing for the denuclearization of the Korean peninsula and peace and stability in the region,” Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying told press briefings repeatedly.
   Wang Dong, a professor of international studies at Peking University, said China is being scapegoated.
   “China can’t afford to be the scapegoat. What happened was the Trump administration is divided on its approach toward the procedures of denuclearization. [Pompeo] proposed a hawkish approach [during negotiations], which Pyongyang will never accept. North Korea has made it clear that its principle of step-by-step and simultaneous action has to be abided by,” Wang said, adding that both Washington and Pyongyang need to make compromises to narrow their gaps.
   The professor urged Trump not to offset his diplomatic efforts after the Singapore summit, saying he should next persuade his hawkish aides to come up with a feasible approach on “full denuclearization” — one that differs from the past complete, verifiable and irreversible dismantlement (CVID) of North Korea’s nuclear programs.
    ...While China may be genuinely committed to pushing Pyongyang to denuclearize, it’ll inevitably bear the brunt of any back-and-forth from North Korea’s delivery, according to Tsai Tung-Chieh, a professor of international politics at National Chung Hsing University in Taichung, central Taiwan.
     That’s because Pyongyang can only look to China, currently its major trade partner, for economic gains in exchange for any progress of its denuclearization, the professor said.  North Korea leader Kim Jung Un has invited Chinese President Xi Jinping to visit Pyongyang in September for National Day celebrations in a bid to strengthen economic ties.
     ...“Denuclearization will be next used as a bargaining chip and guarantee for North Korea to negotiate for [future] economic incomes. That is, the North won’t terminate nuclear programs without any economic gains,” Tsai said.  After the Singapore summit, Trump may have eroded China’s leverage by directly engaging with Pyongyang, but that doesn’t mean China will be left completely out of the equation, the professor said.
     ...Wang, in addition, disagreed that Kim is planning on a second summit with Trump in Switzerland as he said such a summit isn’t in the interests of either country.  What Pyongyang really wants is a four-party meeting with South Korea, China and the United States, the professor said.  “Pyongyang has more faith in South Korea and China. It remains skeptical of the U.S. To Kim, he will be under a lot of pressure shall he next meet one-on-one with Trump. Instead, he will feel more eased sided by South Korea and China and can certainly leverage the three-to-one advantage to constrain the U.S.” Tsai said. https://borneobulletin.com.bn/chinas-june-trade-with-north-korea-falls-by-more-than-half/
(AP) China’s imports from North Korea plunged 92.6 per cent in June compared with a year earlier under United Nations (UN) sanctions imposed to stop Pyongyang’s nuclear and missile programmes, the customs agency said yesterday.  Exports of Chinese oil and other goods to the North fell 40.6 per cent, a customs agency spokesman, Huang Songping, said at a news conference. He gave no financial totals.
     ...China provides nearly all of the isolated North’s trade and energy supplies. Beijing has imposed limits on oil exports and sharply reduced North Korean revenue by banning purchases of its textiles, seafood and coal.  
     Beijing was long Pyongyang’s diplomatic protector but has supported the UN sanctions out of frustration at what Chinese leaders see as their neighbour’s increasingly reckless behaviour.
     Beijing also ordered North Korean-owned restaurants and other businesses in China, an important revenue source, to close.
     In the first six months of the year, Chinese imports fell 88.7 per cent from the same period of 2017 to 690 million yuan (USD103 million), according to Huang. Exports declined 43.1 per cent to 6.4 billion yuan (USD960 million).  Huang said Chinese exports to the North have declined for 11 straight months, while imports have declined for 10 months.
     Beijing has “consistently implemented” the UN trade curbs, Huang said.
     Also yesterday, a deputy Chinese foreign minister sounded a reassuring note about North Korea after Trump complained Beijing might be disrupting diplomatic efforts due to its trade dispute with Washington.  The official, Kong Xuanyou, said there has been “positive momentum” and Beijing is in “close coordination” with Washington. https://thediplomat.com/2018/07/china-is-standing-in-the-way-of-north-korea-negotiations/
      ...But there is an even bigger hurdle faced by the Trump administration. North Korea denuclearizing was always highly unlikely, but any meaningful deal between North Korea and the U.S. that leads to better relations — even just securing stockpiles and reduced quantities of missiles — is likely to be hindered by China. For a time, Beijing cooperated with America’s “maximum pressure” sanctions. But now China is loosening enforcement at the North Korean-Chinese border and granting the Kim regime much-needed access to foreign currency. This strengthens North Korea’s negotiating position against America.
     ...Under threat of a crackdown on China’s export-machine, Beijing went along with Trump’s maximum pressure plan. But that put China in an awkward position. China became the “bad cop,” imposing tough sanctions, while the United States — in Trumpian fashion — was promising to make North Korea rich. China holds the stick, and the U.S. holds the carrot. This situation was, and is, undesirable for China. Because North Korea borders China, it will work against any pivot by North Korea toward the United States.
     And China has good reason to believe Kim would make a modest pivot if the price were right — not to being a U.S. ally, of course, but at least away from China and toward the rest of the world — given the deficiency of trust between China and North Korea. Some of this stems from ancient history.  https://www.cnbc.com/2018/07/12/south-korea-increases-engagement-with-north-korea.html

There might be reason for Xi or (more likely despite the promise to return Kim's visit) one of his highest cabinet members still with all the things going on, but seems unlikely in the immediate future.
KJU planning a third visit to meet with Xi. Hard to imagine Xi needing to go to NK anytime soon.

I think China wants to stay on top of its leadership role in East Asia and over North Korea in particular.  But I think going to North Korea right away is likely to make North Korea / Kim look more important right now than less.  Especially if Trump ends up in Pyongyang), I don't see China following suit.  Nor do I see them rushing off to Pyongyang to beat Trump to the punch; it's not such a significant move for them and is far more likley to make them look weak rather than strong.  Plus they have little to lose from Kim grandstanding since they still hold most of the cards...and much more to gain by expanding diplomatic power in Asia and elsewhere while the Trump and Kim flirt.  And there are a many parties in Asia who would rely more on a rational, steady, slow-to-act, economically-driven power close to home that are being left out by Trump's current US policy and already wondering what the role in in a changing power dynamic in Asia.  China has maintained support for North Korea in its media: suggesting sanctions be lifted (opposing Trump's wait for denuclearization),  through opening air travel to Pyongyang and escorting Kim to Singapore, etc.  They've also been stepping up other diplomatic activities in the region.  I know that Chinese officials said back in May that Xi would probably visit North Korea "sometime after the summit" as a reciprocal diplomatic action, but postponing until they're good and ready seems more likely.  Kim on the other hand is likely to make the most of his own international diplomatic activities, even more so if China delays, I would think.  Furthermore, with so much left off the table and pending concrete decisions and actions, there's a much better chance that China can push for talks among many players and further discussions.  It still seems to me that China is unlikely to send anyone so high level to visit until after things are more settled. https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/06/12/donald-trump-accepts-kim-jong-uns-invitation-visit-north-korea/

It still seems to me that this is unlikely to happen before August or October, partly because the traditional Chinese leadership visits seem to be to show normal/status quo relations between the countries rather than planning/policy-heavy summits in any way, and partly because they seem to be 2-3 months after activity when things have calmed.   If the Trump/Kim meeting does go forward in Singapore, and especially if China ends up being there (thanks @JMR2017 for the link http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/733893), I think there is likely to be a slightly longer delay for a formal visit with more emphasis on phone/other diplomatic communication than formal face-to-face visits from top Chinese officials.  The bigger the stakes now, the less likely I think a formal state visit to be in the near future.  These things also usually take time to plan, and even if something is vaguely in the works now, I think the ultimate certainty of a visit taking place or a time being set depends a great deal on what happens this summer, how talks go and what's discussed, and in the end what's agreed upon.   And that leaves a great deal contingent on something that is either very new and uncharted (actual denuclearization in North Korea and opening of normal diplomatic relations with many other countries) and at the same time very fragile with a strong precedent for falling apart (historically, DPRK has been more likely to delay or cancel talks, not follow through on promises to cooperate with countries that are traditionally "enemies" or threats, and even do respond unexpectedly or aggressively).  Add to that the general unpredictability of President Trump and the need for American to come across looking strong and to push aggressively against North Korea in a way that requires them to show force / power in kind to save face and I think the likelihood of things going smoothly to be pretty small. China has a lot to gain from a more stable and economically integrated North Korea, but they don't have a lot to gain from sending high level politicians up to North Korea, looking like they're involved moderately or deeply in what North Korea ends up doing (for good or for bad), and then getting backlash if North Korea goes rogue and disappoints the world.  In fact, I think they have quite a bit to gain from being calm, moderate, friendly and helpful, but not closely connected with the summer activities, at least not in any very public way.  I'm sure they're very involved in managing outcomes behind the scenes.  And a personal visit north is very public and politically significant in China and in the region, I think of declaring good/normal relations, general influence, cooperation, and support.  If things go well this summer, there may be additional meetings or events involving more countries or Asian leadership, very likely China, and that would probably also delay the kind of one-on-one trip north by a Politburo member - possible 1-2 months after any major meetings or discussions from the summer.  If things go badly, I imagine there would be at least 2-3 months before a Politburo member goes north to visit, but depending on how and why things go poorly, there may be just as much reason for China to cancel it's promise to send Xi or someone close to him to North Korea for a reciprocal visit.  In a face-saving culture where the kind of tensions present now make saving face even more important, I think there is a lot working against a visit in the near future even if there is reason to think China will start sending leadership north again after ceasing to do so a few years back.  But I think the earliest it is likely to be August, more likely Oct or November.   Even if things go well, China won't rush up to Pyongyang to sort things out if they can do that in other ways.  China has lots of ways to put pressure on North Korea without a direct visit, and a direct visit in the midst of or soon after diplomatic changes could do more harm than good, with little value for China in the process.  The most likely reason to send a top politician north is to show that all has been settled nicely.

South Korea's national security director on Monday praised the role of Chinese President Xi Jinping's administration in nudging North Korea toward denuclearization talks, following word of a possible summit between President Donald Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. Chung Eui-yong briefed China's top foreign policy adviser, Yang Jiechi, on the recent inter-Korean talks and was to meet with Xi later in the day. "Our president, Moon Jae-in, and the (South Korean) government believe that various advances toward achieving the goal of peace and denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula were made with active support and contribution from President Xi Jinping and the Chinese government," Chung told Yang. Yang said China insists on all parties "sticking to solving the issue through dialogue and consultation."

I believe that China just no longer has a reason to support or be friendly with North Korea given its nuclear capabilities, effective or not. As this article hypothesises (https://www.brookings.edu/essay/the-education-of-kim-jong-un/), the NK regime probably feels that it must have nuclear weapons. IF that's the case, then surely the Chinese of all people would have gotten that feeling years ago. So given those hard feelings of the North Koreans, which they have discouraged publicly as well, then what's the point of China being friendly with NK if it can't restrain its nuclear capabilities? Especially given that continued friendliness with NK might mean economic retaliation from the US, and conversely, that friendliness with NK wouldn't bring China any benefits, why would they be friendly.  However, this does assume that the Chinese feel that war won't break out if they are not friendly with the NKs. Which is logical, given the large costs involved on all sides if war is to start. But this is just my rationalisation of my forecast.

Adjusting again. https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/north-korea-agrees-to-send-athletes-to-winter-olympics-south-says/2018/01/09/56407aa8-f4a9-11e7-9af7-a50bc3300042_story.html?utm_term=.97fcc872a32e I think that it makes sense that China would take a lead role in brokering a historic agreement between NK and SK. In prep for that, I think the likelihood has changed that China will send a top leader to visit with NK. Part of this has to do with the US and SK breaking; the US-first policy that Trump is driving; the larger world role that Xi has said he would take. There are clearly other reasons to visit but this is a significant change that re-balances the benefit to China to visit with a high level official.  Question really comes down to sooner or later this year.... hard to say but I'd venture that as NK/SK relations improve, China will move to get involved.

I think the regularity of China's visits, including Politburo Standing Committee members, suggests a visit is fairly likely despite tensions and that it is likely to continue to be so since the appearance of relative stability in dialogue between the Communist groups is more important than public rebuffs.  Even when relations seem cool or visits seem to demonstrate issues, they've maintained public amicability and efforts to work together, though less recently.  Visits have increased during special events (Kim Jong Il's end/Kim Jong Un's succession to Chairman of the WPK, National Congress elections in China every 5 years, etc.  In the last several years, visits also seem to come the month *after* major headlines from Korea on nuclear activity, esp. regarding plans for expanding nuclear activity (moreso than in relation to launches or nuclear activity).   I can't see that China's delegations of top political members are primarily ways to manipulate N. Korea, though I imagine the discussions end up leaning that way fairly strongly regardless of what official reports say.  And it seems that Kim Jong Un has been showing signs of resisting China's pressure, and China's support of recent UN resolutions on sanctions seems to support growing distance.  And Xi doesn't seem especially committed to high level visits to NK, maybe because of declining relations (as others have noted and has been in the news, over NK's increased aggressive nuclear testing, assassination of Jang Song Thaek, etc) or just because Xi's vision for aggressive economic expansion has very little room for the kind of martial and political grandstanding Kim Jong Un is seeking and Xi's foreign policy seems much less direct or overtly domineering than his domestic policies.  Even then, Xi is good at waiting and looking for key moments and mechanisms of leverage rather than forcing the situation, I think.   I can see why nuclear talks might increase the likelihood of a visit in the spring, though I guess the real communication would be through less direct means, if for no other reason than Kim doesn't want to look like they're under China's thumb.  Also such high level visits from China seem to come after major decisions, possibly as a means of sorting out what the decision will mean for future relations, and not before or during major decisions out of N. Korea as a means of exerting pressure to act a certain way.  Visits during or near the Olympics seem unlikely to me with everything going on.  And as mwokasch suggested, visits tend to happen in the second half of the year (because of a structural limit to number of annual visits?) http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/606127  I'd guess there's maybe a 30-40% chance of a politburo standing committee member visiting this year, probably during the last half of the year, and most likely not until October or November Other helpful comments & links:

China uses such visits as a method of control: Kim Jong-un will have to make concessions for China to even consider such a visit. There is a chance that China will honor Kim's attempts in deescalation regarding the Olympic Winter Games, but not a very probable one. There also is a chance that China will use such a visit as a bargaining chip to stop a potential vicious cycle of escalation ater the autumn maneuver hosted by the US and South Korea in october. Since such a cycle takes its time, it's most probable that such a visit will take place around four to six weeks after the maneuver, which means that the earliest point of time would be in november.

A kind person on Twitter provided me with evidence that Kim Jong Un met with Liu Yunshan in 2015, several years after he retired from the Politburo Standing Committee in 2012; and that Kim Jong Un also visited the Cuban embassy in Pyongyang after Fidel's death last year. So it is not out of the question that if a member of the Politburo Standing Committee were to visit North Korea, that Kim Jong Un would meet him. That said, this is not, so far, much of a track record of interactions with diplomats. Base rate of one diplomat per year? If anyone has evidence of more meetings with diplomats, I would like to hear from you. On the other hand, it is not necessary for Kim Jong Un to agree to participate in discussions, or even be photographed shaking hands in order for a Politburo Standing Committee member to go to North Korea.
Would take escalation of the current situation for China to send someone there. More likely China to invite high-ranking North Koreans to Beijing.

First baby step toward such a visit, a "special envoy." Note that this is described as "The highest level Chinese envoy to North Korea in two years." This suggests a base rate of far less than one higher level envoy per year, but higher than zero.  Power player analysis: Xi may have ample motivation to persuade Trump that he is responding to Trump's implied, "Don't just stand there, do something." He might therefore, follow up with a higher level envoy, possibly even a member of the Poltiburo Standing Committee. On the other hand, relations between China and North Korea have been frosty since the Kim Jong Un regime's  execution of Jang Song Thaek, Kim Jong Un's uncle, who was a diplomat well respected by China's leaders,. The recent assassination of Kim Jong Un's older half-brother,  Kim Jong Nam,  followed by news that seven North Korean spies were secretly dispatched to China on a mission to kill Kim Han Sol, the eldest son of Kim Jong Nam,  seems likely to have worsened relations.  Also of note, a girl band that included an ex-girlfriend of Kim Jong un was unceremoniously expelled from China, causing their performances to be cancelled.  Meanwhile, China has repeatedly complained about North Korean soldiers sneaking over the border to rob and kill Chinese citizens.  So I expect that in order to maintain the respect of the public, Xi must tread lightly and circumspectlfully in any relations with this creepy leadership. If even permitting a performance by a girl band linked to Dear Leader was a bridge too far, what about a member of the Standing Committee visiting? Images of red carpet, handshakes, with various grinning North Koreans? Refusal, as always, of Kim Jong Un to meet with any diplomat or world leader whatsoever? How dare any Chinese official think he could be granted an audience with the Great Leader? How humiliating! Dateline 11-17-2017 The highest-level Chinese envoy to North Korea in two years arrived in the country’s capital on Friday to try to improve relations that have soured over Beijing’s tightening of sanctions and expressions of support for U.S. President Donald Trump’s calls for more pressure on the North to abandon its nuclear weapons program. Song Tao’s official mission is to brief North Korean officials on the outcome of China’s ruling Communist Party congress held last month. He is visiting as President Xi Jinping’s special envoy, according to Chinese and North Korean state media, but no other details about his itinerary or whether he will meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un have been announced.  -- https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/high-level-chinese-envoy-heads-to-north-korea-amid-chill/2017/11/16/be6066ae-cb49-11e7-b506-8a10ed11ecf5_story.html

Haven't seen a good analysis of this yet so thought I'd share what I knew on the subject (which is limited): Most important aspects first: 
1) On Average there has been at least 1 visit to North Korea per Year. 
2) There is increased activity following elections (every 5 years) 
3) There is pressure for them to make a visit 
4) The distribution of the month of visit is most certainly not random. Very few visits occur in the early part of the year. I suspect that this is a result of the structural limit on the number of visits that may be conducted annually. 
5) There is a 45/55 (visits to Korea / Visits to China) distribution of who visits which country. More recently this has seemed to alternate back & forth, suggesting it is China's turn to visit North Korea, though I could be fooled by randomness here. Taking all of this into account results in my prediction distribution. Note:  Corrected the mis-alignment of quarterly results.
